The Space Pirates toolkit includes unique loaders and several backdoors that we have not seen before, and, presumably, are specific to the group: MyKLoadClient, BH_A006, Deed RAT. Attackers also have access to the Zupdax backdoor: its modern versions use a similar execution scheme to MyKLoadClient, but the backdoor code itself dates back to 2010 and cannot be uniquely tied to a group.

PT ESC : Space Pirates .

Separately, it is worth noting the connection between the groups Space Pirates and TA428. As part of one of the investigations, we observed the activity of both groups on infected computers, which, however, had no intersections in the network infrastructure. At the same time, during Operation StealthyTrident, described by ESET , the attackers used Tmanger, attributed to TA428, and Zupdax, associated with Space Pirates. The connection of another TA428 malware, in particular Albaniiutas (RemShell), and Zupdax can also be traced in the network infrastructure adjacent to that mentioned in the ESET report. All this suggests that Space Pirates and TA428 can join forces and share tools, network resources and access to infected systems.

While investigating the activities of Space Pirates, we found a large number of overlaps with previously identified activity that the researchers associated with the Winnti (APT41), Bronze Union (APT27), TA428, RedFoxtrot, Mustang Panda and Night Dragon groups. The reason for this is probably the exchange of tools between groups - a frequent occurrence for APT groups in the Asian region.

We assume that Space Pirates has Asian roots, as evidenced by the heavy use of Chinese in resources, SFX archives, and PDB paths. In addition, the groups arsenal includes the Royal Road RTF (or 8.t) builder, which is common among Asian hackers, and the PcShare backdoor, and almost all intersections with already known activity are associated with APT groups in the Asian region.

The identified malicious activity could not be unambiguously associated with any of the known hacker groups, so we gave the attackers a new name - Space Pirates. The reason for the name was the string P1Rat, used by attackers in PDB paths, and the focus of some attacks on the aerospace industry. This report describes the detected activity of the group, the specifics of the malware it uses, as well as its links to other APT groups.

At least two attacks on Russian organizations can be considered successful. In the first case, the attackers gained access to at least 20 servers in the corporate network, where they were present for about 10 months. During this time, more than 1,500 internal documents were stolen, as well as information about all employee accounts in one of the network domains. In the second case, the attackers managed to gain a foothold in the company's network for more than a year, obtain information about the computers included in the network, and install their malware on at least 12 corporate nodes in three different regions.

In the summer of 2021, PT Expert Security Center revealed traces of a compromise of another enterprise. The organization has been informed. As a result of the investigation, we found connections on her computers to the same network infrastructure. Further research made it possible to identify at least two more organizations in Russia that were attacked using the same malware and network infrastructure, both with state participation.

Some attacks using malware from the APT group have also targeted Chinese financial companies, which may indicate a monetary motivation. All potential victims have been notified through national CERTs.

This malware has been used in attacks against Russian organizations, including government agencies and aerospace companies, and was often distributed through spear phishing. As analysis of the letters shows, Chinese companies providing financial services also became victims.

Separately, it is worth noting the connection between the groups Space Pirates and TA428. As part of one of the investigations, we observed the activity of both groups on infected computers, which, however, had no intersections in the network infrastructure. At the same time, during Operation StealthyTrident, described by ESET , the attackers used Tmanger, attributed to TA428, and Zupdax, associated with Space Pirates. The connection of another TA428 malware, in particular Albaniiutas (RemShell), and Zupdax can also be traced in the network infrastructure adjacent to that mentioned in the ESET report. All this suggests that Space Pirates and TA428 can join forces and share tools, network resources and access to infected systems.
Analysis of malware and tools

In addition, the attackers also use well-known malware: PlugX, ShadowPad, Poison Ivy, a modified version of PcShare, and the public ReVBShell shell . The dog-tunnel utility is used to tunnel traffic .

Key links between affected organizations, malware families and network infrastructure fragments, as well as public information about attackers can be seen in Fig. 1. Later in the report we will talk about them in more detail.

The identified malicious activity could not be unambiguously associated with any of the known hacker groups, so we gave the attackers a new name - Space Pirates. The reason for the name was the string P1Rat, used by attackers in PDB paths, and the focus of some attacks on the aerospace industry. This report describes the detected activity of the group, the specifics of the malware it uses, as well as its links to other APT groups.

sentences: This malware has been used in attacks against Russian organizations, including government agencies and aerospace companies, and was often distributed through spear phishing. As analysis of the letters shows, Chinese companies providing financial services also became victims.

At the end of 2019, specialists from the Positive Technologies security expert center ( PT Expert Security Center , PT ESC) discovered a phishing email targeting one of the enterprises in the Russian aerospace industry. It contained a link to previously unknown malware. Our experts discovered the same malware in 2020 while investigating an information security incident in one of the Russian government organizations. In the course of this work, several new malware families were also discovered using a common network infrastructure, while some of them were not previously mentioned in open sources.

We assume that Space Pirates has Asian roots, as evidenced by the heavy use of Chinese in resources, SFX archives, and PDB paths. In addition, the groups arsenal includes the Royal Road RTF (or 8.t) builder, which is common among Asian hackers, and the PcShare backdoor, and almost all intersections with already known activity are associated with APT groups in the Asian region.

The Space Pirates toolkit includes unique loaders and several backdoors that we have not seen before, and, presumably, are specific to the group: MyKLoadClient, BH_A006, Deed RAT. Attackers also have access to the Zupdax backdoor: its modern versions use a similar execution scheme to MyKLoadClient, but the backdoor code itself dates back to 2010 and cannot be uniquely tied to a group.

The Space Pirates toolkit includes unique loaders and several backdoors that we have not seen before, and, presumably, are specific to the group: MyKLoadClient, BH_A006, Deed RAT. Attackers also have access to the Zupdax backdoor: its modern versions use a similar execution scheme to MyKLoadClient, but the backdoor code itself dates back to 2010 and cannot be uniquely tied to a group.

At the end of 2019, specialists from the Positive Technologies security expert center ( PT Expert Security Center , PT ESC) discovered a phishing email targeting one of the enterprises in the Russian aerospace industry. It contained a link to previously unknown malware. Our experts discovered the same malware in 2020 while investigating an information security incident in one of the Russian government organizations. In the course of this work, several new malware families were also discovered using a common network infrastructure, while some of them were not previously mentioned in open sources.
PT ESC : Space Pirates .

In the summer of 2021, PT Expert Security Center revealed traces of a compromise of another enterprise. The organization has been informed. As a result of the investigation, we found connections on her computers to the same network infrastructure. Further research made it possible to identify at least two more organizations in Russia that were attacked using the same malware and network infrastructure, both with state participation.

The identified malicious activity could not be unambiguously associated with any of the known hacker groups, so we gave the attackers a new name - Space Pirates. The reason for the name was the string P1Rat, used by attackers in PDB paths, and the focus of some attacks on the aerospace industry. This report describes the detected activity of the group, the specifics of the malware it uses, as well as its links to other APT groups.

We assume that Space Pirates has Asian roots, as evidenced by the heavy use of Chinese in resources, SFX archives, and PDB paths. In addition, the groups arsenal includes the Royal Road RTF (or 8.t) builder, which is common among Asian hackers, and the PcShare backdoor, and almost all intersections with already known activity are associated with APT groups in the Asian region.

We assume that Space Pirates has Asian roots, as evidenced by the heavy use of Chinese in resources, SFX archives, and PDB paths. In addition, the groups arsenal includes the Royal Road RTF (or 8.t) builder, which is common among Asian hackers, and the PcShare backdoor, and almost all intersections with already known activity are associated with APT groups in the Asian region.

Separately, it is worth noting the connection between the groups Space Pirates and TA428. As part of one of the investigations, we observed the activity of both groups on infected computers, which, however, had no intersections in the network infrastructure. At the same time, during Operation StealthyTrident, described by ESET , the attackers used Tmanger, attributed to TA428, and Zupdax, associated with Space Pirates. The connection of another TA428 malware, in particular Albaniiutas (RemShell), and Zupdax can also be traced in the network infrastructure adjacent to that mentioned in the ESET report. All this suggests that Space Pirates and TA428 can join forces and share tools, network resources and access to infected systems.

Some attacks using malware from the APT group have also targeted Chinese financial companies, which may indicate a monetary motivation. All potential victims have been notified through national CERTs.

At least two attacks on Russian organizations can be considered successful. In the first case, the attackers gained access to at least 20 servers in the corporate network, where they were present for about 10 months. During this time, more than 1,500 internal documents were stolen, as well as information about all employee accounts in one of the network domains. In the second case, the attackers managed to gain a foothold in the company's network for more than a year, obtain information about the computers included in the network, and install their malware on at least 12 corporate nodes in three different regions.

The Space Pirates toolkit includes unique loaders and several backdoors that we have not seen before, and, presumably, are specific to the group: MyKLoadClient, BH_A006, Deed RAT. Attackers also have access to the Zupdax backdoor: its modern versions use a similar execution scheme to MyKLoadClient, but the backdoor code itself dates back to 2010 and cannot be uniquely tied to a group.

The Space Pirates toolkit includes unique loaders and several backdoors that we have not seen before, and, presumably, are specific to the group: MyKLoadClient, BH_A006, Deed RAT. Attackers also have access to the Zupdax backdoor: its modern versions use a similar execution scheme to MyKLoadClient, but the backdoor code itself dates back to 2010 and cannot be uniquely tied to a group.

In addition, the attackers also use well-known malware: PlugX, ShadowPad, Poison Ivy, a modified version of PcShare, and the public ReVBShell shell . The dog-tunnel utility is used to tunnel traffic .

The group's core network infrastructure uses a small number of IP addresses pointed to by DDNS domains. Interestingly, the attackers use not only third-level domains, but also fourth and subsequent ones, for example, w.asd3.as.amazon-corp.wikaba.com.

While investigating the activities of Space Pirates, we found a large number of overlaps with previously identified activity that the researchers associated with the Winnti (APT41), Bronze Union (APT27), TA428, RedFoxtrot, Mustang Panda and Night Dragon groups. The reason for this is probably the exchange of tools between groups - a frequent occurrence for APT groups in the Asian region.

The Space Pirates toolkit includes unique loaders and several backdoors that we have not seen before, and, presumably, are specific to the group: MyKLoadClient, BH_A006, Deed RAT. Attackers also have access to the Zupdax backdoor: its modern versions use a similar execution scheme to MyKLoadClient, but the backdoor code itself dates back to 2010 and cannot be uniquely tied to a group.

The identified malicious activity could not be unambiguously associated with any of the known hacker groups, so we gave the attackers a new name - Space Pirates. The reason for the name was the string P1Rat, used by attackers in PDB paths, and the focus of some attacks on the aerospace industry. This report describes the detected activity of the group, the specifics of the malware it uses, as well as its links to other APT groups.
2011 McAfee , Night Dragon. , , Redsip (e3165c2691dc27ddaeb21e007f2bf5aeb14ef3e12ec007938e104d6aed512f39).

While investigating the activities of Space Pirates, we found a large number of overlaps with previously identified activity that the researchers associated with the Winnti (APT41), Bronze Union (APT27), TA428, RedFoxtrot, Mustang Panda and Night Dragon groups. The reason for this is probably the exchange of tools between groups - a frequent occurrence for APT groups in the Asian region.

associated: The identified malicious activity could not be unambiguously associated with any of the known hacker groups, so we gave the attackers a new name - Space Pirates

In addition, the groups arsenal includes the Royal Road RTF (or 8.t) builder, which is common among Asian hackers, and the PcShare backdoor, and almost all intersections with already known activity are associated with APT groups in the Asian region

While investigating the activities of Space Pirates, we found a large number of overlaps with previously identified activity that the researchers associated with the Winnti (APT41), Bronze Union (APT27), TA428, RedFoxtrot, Mustang Panda and Night Dragon groups
At the same time, during Operation StealthyTrident, described by ESET , the attackers used Tmanger, attributed to TA428, and Zupdax, associated with Space Pirates
targets: This malware has been used in attacks against Russian organizations, including government agencies and aerospace companies, and was often distributed through spear phishing
attributed: At the same time, during Operation StealthyTrident, described by ESET , the attackers used Tmanger, attributed to TA428, and Zupdax, associated with Space Pirates
